awd_titl_txt: NeTS:  EAGER:  Exploring 60G HZ based Wireless Body Area Networks for mHealth Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to explore 60 gigahertz (GHz) communication for mobile health (mHealth) applications and build a strong theoretical foundation for designing and evaluating 60GHz Wireless Body Area Network (WBAN) performance. Deep understanding will be gained on the fundamental limits of current 2.4GHz-band WBAN in mHealth applications and the promising benefits of 60GHz body area communication, in terms of its smaller device size, higher data rates, reliability, energy efficiency, safety and security. The outcomes of this research significantly advance the discovery and development of theories and algorithms for designing and evaluating 60GHz WBANs, accelerating wider and faster mHealth applications and consequently addressing escalating healthcare costs worldwide.  The proposed research is tightly coupled to a strong educational component. The planned outreach activities help motivate and attract minority students, and meet increasing demands from a diverse group of government and industry partners. The proposed project has a favorable impact on both graduate and undergraduate training and education.

The research project establishes the theoretical foundation to support the channel modeling, energy efficiency, and security protection for 60GHz WBANs. This research is challenging due to the unique radio propagation pattern of 60G Hz body area communication, energy and security issues for resource-constrained devices in WBANs. Unlike the traditional 2.4G band communication, using the 60GHz band for WBAN has significant advantages in its compact network coverage, device miniaturization, efficient frequency reuse, reduced interference with adjacent wireless body-centric networks, and high data rates. The project includes (1) developing a new channel modeling for 60GHz WBAN communication; (2) improving energy efficiency in 60GHz WBAN through resource allocations; (3) establishing its security mechanism based on channel reciprocity; (4) conducting performance evaluation for 60GHz WBAN communication. The proposed studies employ new statistical modeling approaches to characterize the 60GHz communication channel over body area, improve its power efficiency and security protection. This research project is especially valuable to mHealth applications, advances the WBAN literature, and may provide new guidelines for the 60GHz WBAN design and deployment.

por.por_cntn:
Health monitoring of patients' vital signs over Wireless Body Area Networks (WBANs) provides a cost effective solution to the healthcare system. WBANs face significant challenges in terms of data rates, network coverage, device miniaturization, efficient frequency, and communication interference. This project explores 60 Gigahertz (GHz) communication for mobile health (mHealth) applications and builds a strong theoretical foundation for designing and evaluating 60GHz Wireless Body Area Network (WBAN) performance. Unlike the traditional 2.4G band communication, using the 60GHz band for WBAN (Wireless Body Area Networks) has significant advantages. For example, the project develops a new channel modeling for 60GHz WBAN communication and conducts the quantitative comparisons between the 60 GHz and the 2.4 GHz based WBANs, and the outcome shows that the 60 GHz based PHY (Physical layer) performs better over the 2.4 GHz based PHY in terms of system capacity, network coverage and device miniaturizations. In addition, a new game theory based approaches to address resource allocation and WBAN coexistence issues is proposed to increase both energy efficiency and network throughput. The project also develops physical layer security approaches (e.g., key agreement and authentication) for WBANs by utilizing wireless channel reciprocity. The channel reciprocity and key generation rate are closely related to channel dynamics, frequency, mobility and environments, which show the differences in mmWave WBANs compared with 2.4 GHz WBANs. The project establishes the theoretical foundation to support the channel modeling, energy efficiency, and security protection for 60GHz WBANs. Several principles have been derived to guide 60GHz communication system design and deployment of WBAN mHealth applications.

Findings from the proposed project offer new methods and algorithms for designing and evaluating 60GHz WBANs, accelerating wider and faster mHealth applications and consequently addressing escalating healthcare costs worldwide. The proposed research also advances the fields of WBANs security and trustworthy computing for healthcare applications. The proposed theories, models, algorithms have been reported in conferences, journals and classes, which can be used by engineers and researchers to design 60GHz WBAN for mHealth applications. In addition, the proposed research is tightly coupled to a strong educational component. It recruits and educates future generation of engineers and scientists, which meets increasing demands from a diverse group of government and industry partners. This objective has been accomplished through curriculum development, student mentoring, and community outreach in these fast changing technical fields. The proposed project has a favorable impact on both graduate and undergraduate training and education.
